abstract.text: Market reforms have been given much of the credit for China's spectacular growth performance. 6 This paper looks at China's reform process systematically with India's and argues that the 7 Chinese state has played a key role in transforming China into a modern economic state, 8 deploying unlimited supplies of labor and combining it with a variety of initiatives in a 9 pragmatic, nonideological way to promote public and private investment and create productive 10 employment in agricultural, manufacturing, and service sectors. India's reforms have been 11 sporadic and are still a work in progress. The record-breaking expansion of China's financial 12 system in fostering investments was overlooked, but has attracted considerable attention in 13 recent years. Is China unique, or are lessons from the Chinese experience for public policy and 14 its sequencing transferrable for agricultural and structural transformation in countries lagging 15 behind, including India? 16 17

FIGREF1.text: s share of value-added and employment in agriculture in total GDP has declined faster 191 than India's (Fig. 2). Industry share in value-added peaked at 48 percent, remaining higher than 192 India's, with a decline in recent years and a change in the industrial structure. State-owned 193 enterprises (SOEs) created substantial employment for labor released from agriculture, following 194 spectacular productivity growth in the 1980s, but unchecked SOE expansion resulted from local 195 governments' financing enterprises via a combination of sales of land, taxation, and bank 196 borrowing, leading to questions of their efficiency and transparency. Since the 1980s, SOEs have 197 undergone major fiscal and monetary reforms, reining in non-performing bank loans. Many 198 inefficient downstream TVEs in consumer and intermediate sectors have failed, with the 199 remainder aiming to become more efficient and competitive, creating employment while meeting 200 growing consumer demand. SOEs remain dominant in the large-scale heavy industry sector, such 201 as semi-conductors, telecoms, energy, steel, and defense, but there, too, reforms are underway to 202 make them more efficient and productive. Perhaps, the best indicator of competitiveness, 203 manufactured goods accounted for 80 percent of exports in the 1980s, of which labor-intensive 204 goods comprised about two-thirds of manufactured exports. China's export basket has 205 diversified. The share of textiles and clothing in exports has decreased. Exports of high 206 technology machinery, transport equipment, and telecommunication equipment have increased to nearly half of China's exports. A striking feature is the rapid increase in imports of raw 208 materials, with China becoming a leader of global value chains (Agarwal and Whalley, 2013; 209 World Bank and WTO, 2019).

Comparative analysis of the reforms and of state investments in India and China 221 222 The Chinese state has played a key role in addressing internal structural issues of an overall 223 strategy, secure land titles, human capital, and infrastructure, explaining China's extraordinarily 224 rapid transformation from agriculture, with unlimited supplies of labor to a modern industrial 225 state. Attributing China's superior performance mainly to market reforms, most studies 226 understate the critical role of the state, underemphasizing its lessons for lagging countries.227Lessons include long-term vision and consistency; substantial investments in public goods; and 228 experimentation, adaptation, scaling up; and evolution based on lessons learned. The implementation of the household responsibility system (HRS) in China was a "market" reform,230    returning collectivized land to farm households, allowing households to make farming decisions.231 HRS was followed by unprecedented rates of investments in agricultural research and 232 development (R&D) (ASTI 2019) and accompanied by physical infrastructure, education, and 233 institutional reforms in the agricultural and rural sector, directly and indirectly contributing to 234 China's extraordinary economic transformation [see supplementary Fig. A.3]. 235 236 With slowing globalization and world trade, the external and internal environments for both are 237 less favorable in 2019, than prior to the Global Financial Crisis (GFC). India's Economic Survey 238 (MOF, 2018, 68) noted the potential risk of a "late converger stall" from backlash against 239 globalization. However, The Economist (2019) has argued that causes of India's less than stellar 240 performance are domestic, that successive governments-state as well as national-have failed 241 to promote sensible, consistent policies to promote growth. China has had an exceptional record 242 of speedy design, implementation, experimentation, and learning from successes and failures of Chinese reforms: China's three-legged development strategy 246 247 China has displayed a unique blend of political centralization with economic and administrative 248 decentralization, leading it to be a strong conceptualizer and implementer of strategy. In India, 249 political will to adopt tough policies is often limited, reforms are slow to materialize and state 250 capacity to implement the policies has weakened over time (Bardhan, 2020). China's overarching, three-legged strategy is described well by Yukon Huang (2017): (1) 253 agricultural reforms starting with the household responsibility system (HRS); (2) industrial 254 reforms through town and village enterprises (TVEs) metamorphosing into a full-fledged 255 industrialization strategy, by promoting partnerships between local authorities and private 256 entrepreneurs; and (3) establishment of special economic zones (SEZs) in coastal areas, allowing 257 market forces to counter forces that previously benefited well-placed local authorities, while 258 taking steps to foster production for international trade on a highly competitive basis. Until the 259 1980s, when China became member of the Bretton Woods institutions, China was isolated.260Exports were needed to finance imports, and hence, it had a strong incentive to become export-261 oriented (World Bank 2018c) [see supplementary Fig. A.4]. 262 263 With agility, ideological flexibility, and results ranging from physical and human capital, R&D, 264 and institutional reforms of service delivery, China has pursued decentralization of development 265 to provincial and local governments to co-opt, if not overcome vested interests, in the pursuit of 266 "bottom-up" reforms and entrepreneurship on a large scale (Gulati and Fan, 2007; Bardhan, the important areas of reforms were in the trade sector. China's trade-weighted statutory 270 tariffs stood at 40 percent in 1992. In the next decade, before becoming a WTO member in 2001, 271 the tariffs declined to an estimated 7 percent (Huang, 2017). In a comprehensive literature review 272 and analysis of agricultural reforms in transition economies of Asia and Eastern Europe, Rozelle and Swinnen (2004) credited China's market reforms for its performance. Indeed, the narrative 274 of China's market reforms has been a consistent theme in the literature and among international 275 organizations. The World Bank illustrates the point: "Since initiating market reforms in 1978, 276 China has shifted from a centrally planned to a more market-based economy and has experienced 277 rapid economic and social development. GDP growth has averaged nearly 10% a year-the 278 fastest sustained expansion by a major economy in history-and more than 850 million people 279 have lifted themselves out of poverty" (World Bank, 2018b).

FIGREF3.text: Swinnen (2004, 405)  stressed the pragmatism of reforms, noting their gradual 282 sequencing, initially focused on reforming land rights, and attributed the success of agricultural 283 reforms to the "the rise of incentives provided by decollectivization." Huang (2017) noted that 284 agrarian reforms drove the initial surge in production. Growth increased sharply in the first half 285 of the 1980s with the new HRS. Land leases also emerged, shifting user rights from collectives 286 to households. By simply allowing farmers to sell their surplus on the market, increasing 287 procurement prices, and reducing state-mandated quotas, rural per capita incomes tripled 288 between 1978 and 1984. The HRS reforms revealed spectacularly how far below the production 289 possibility frontier that Chinese farmers had been operating before its introduction. The HRS 290 contributed to a surge in GDP growth rate to 14 percent by the mid-1980s. Sicular (1994) 291 discussed the continued quota system and subsidies to grain prices in the 1980s and its gradual 292 reform in the 1990s (see, also, Gulati and Fan, 2007).

India's import-substituting industrialization, aid dependence, and weak role for agriculture 339 in the overall development strategy 340 341 The United States and the West supported India as an antidote to Communist China. India was a 342 founding member of the non-aligned movement. With its colonial experience, Indian leadership 343 embraced an import-substituting industrialization strategy to become a great industrial power, as 344 its once thriving textile and steel industry attested to. India's first balance of payments crisis 345 (1958) led to realization within the World Bank of the growing capital needs of a rapidly 346 industrializing India, prompting the establishment in 1960, of the International Development 347 Association (IDA), the concessional window of the World Bank. Developing countries sought 348 aid through the United Nations, but Western donors opted for establishing IDA in the World 349 Bank and providing technical assistance through the United Nations Development Programme 350 (UNDP) (Lele and Goswami, 2020, forthcoming). India's second and third balance of payments 351 crises occurred in 1964-66 and at the end of the 1980s, respectively. According to Srinivasan 352 (1996), the mid-1960s crisis was a missed opportunity for reforms; but the late 1980s crisis led to 353 major internal reassessment and reform of the industrial and trade policy, led by Finance 354 Minister Manmohan Singh in the Rao Cabinet of the Congress Party (see Mohan, 2017). Until 355 the second financial crisis, the Bank's view about India was that it could do no wrong.356 357 When India's external situation began to deteriorate in 1964-1965, the World Bank mounted the 358 Bell mission, recommending a major devaluation, substantial liberalization, and abandonment of 359 the import-substituting industrialization strategy based on heavy industry, in support of light industrialization to meet the requirements of the growing food and agriculture sector. It has become conventional wisdom among China watchers that 541 accountability of the government and the party at multiple levels to deliver development 542 outcomes is greater, as the primary source of the regime's legitimacy, given the absence of 543 democratic institutions. Government takes delivering results seriously as a means of political 544 stability and indeed barring exceptions of human rights protectors, most of the population is 545 content to see improving standards of living. Effective participation of the poor in development 546 outcomes is weaker in India.
